raw_text:
Stars pay tribute to actor Davis
 
 Hollywood stars including Spike Lee, Burt Reynolds and Oscar nominee Alan Alda have paid tribute to actor Ossie Davis at a funeral in New York.
 
 Veteran star Ossie Davis, a well-known civil rights activist, died in Miami at the age of 87 on 4 February 2005. Friends and family, including actress Ruby Dee his wife of 56 years, gathered at the Riverside Church on Saturday. Also present at the service was former US president Bill Clinton and singer Harry Belafonte, who gave the eulogy. "He would have been a very good president of the United States," said Mr Clinton. "Like most of you here, he gave more to me than I gave to him."
 
 The 87-year-old was found dead last weekend in his hotel room in Florida, where he was making a film. Police said that he appeared to have died of natural causes. Davis made his acting debut in 1950 in No Way Out starring Sidney Poiter. He frequently collaborated with director Spike Lee, starring in seven Lee films including Jungle Fever, Do The Right Thing and Malcolm X. Attallah Shabazz, the daughter of activist Malcolm X, recalled the famous eulogy delivered by Davis at her father's funeral. "Harlem has come to bid farewell to one of its finest hopes," she said, quoting the man she knew as Uncle Ossie. "Ditto." "Ossie was my hero, and he still is," said Aviator star Alan Alda, a family friend for over forty years. "Ossie was a thing of beauty."
 
 "I want so badly someday to have his dignity - a little of it anyway," added Burt Reynolds, Davis's co-star in the 90s TV comedy Evening Shade. Before the midday funeral, scores of Harlem residents formed a queue outside the church to pay their respects to Davis. "It is hard to fathom that we will no longer be able to call on his wisdom, his humour, his loyalty and his moral strength to guide us in the choices that are yet to be made and the battles that are yet to be fought," said Belafonte, himself an ardent civil rights activist who had been friends with Davis for over 60 years. "But how fortunate we were to have him as long as we did."
llama3.2:1b: Stars including Spike Lee, Burt Reynolds, and Oscar nominee Alan Alda pay tribute to actor Ossie Davis at his funeral in New York. He died on February 4, 2005, after being found dead in his hotel room in Florida. Friends and family gave eulogies, praising his acting career, activism, and legacy as a civil rights icon.
llama3.2:3b: Ossie Davis, actor and civil rights activist, died at 87 on February 4, 2005, in Miami from natural causes. Stars including Spike Lee, Burt Reynolds, Alan Alda, Ruby Dee, Bill Clinton, and Harry Belafonte paid tribute to him at his funeral in New York.
gemma2:2b: Ossie Davis, a civil rights activist and acclaimed actor, died at age 87 on February 4th, 2005.  He was remembered fondly by numerous Hollywood stars, including Spike Lee, Burt Reynolds, and Alan Alda.  Bill Clinton and Harry Belafonte delivered eulogies, praising Davis's contributions to the US and his legacy of influence within the Harlem community. Many attendees gathered at the Riverside Church for the funeral, paying tribute to Davis's impact on both entertainment and social change.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Ossie Davis, a famous actor from the Civil Rights Movement, died at 87 in Florida on February 4, 2005. Friends and family gathered at the Riverside Church for his funeral service with Ossie's wife Ruby Dee. He was known for making films like No Way Out and Jungle Fever and had a long career as a film actor. Burt Reynolds said he wanted to have "a little of it" on his behalf, adding that Ossie was a "thing of beauty." Many people mourned the loss of this talented actor who would have been a good president if he were alive.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Hollywood stars paid tribute to Ossie Davis at his funeral in New York, the veteran actor died on February 4th, 2005, making Spike Lee a co-star of seven movies including Jungle Fever. Belafonte gave the eulogy and described him as "a thing of beauty". The service was attended by Ruby Dee, Bill Clinton, Harry Belafonte, Alan Alda, Burt Reynolds, Attallah Shabazz, Spike Lee, and other notable figures who appreciated Davis's contributions to civil rights.
qwen2.5:3b: Hollywood stars such as Spike Lee, Burt Reynolds, and Oscar nominee Alan Alda paid tribute to actor Ossie Davis at his funeral in New York. At 87, Davis was a well-known civil rights activist who made his debut in 1950. He frequently collaborated with director Spike Lee on films like Jungle Fever, Do The Right Thing, and Malcolm X. Davis's wife Ruby Dee and other family members including Attallah Shabazz, the daughter of civil rights leader Malcolm X, also attended the service. Recalling Davis' influential eulogy at Malcolm X's funeral, former US President Bill Clinton praised him as a potential president and said he gave more to Clinton than Clinton gave back. Davis' close friend and co-star in Evening Shade, Burt Reynolds, expressed his admiration for Davis by calling him a "thing of beauty." Davis is remembered for his wisdom, humor, loyalty, and moral strength, and his contributions to civil rights activism.
opencoder:1.5b: Stars pay tribute to actor Ossie Davis at a funeral in New York. Ossie Davis, a well-known civil rights activist, died last weekend in Miami on her father's side. Ruby Dee his wife had gathered at the Riverside Church and she gave the eulogy. She said, "He would have been a very good president of the United States like most of you here he gave more to me than I gave to him." The 87-year-old was found dead in a hotel room where he made a film. The eulogy he received at her father's funeral was an iconic one, and the man she knew as Uncle Ossie also recalls it. It's important to remember that Davis is remembered for his acting debut, which helped him understand the complexities of American culture.

2. The article also mentions that Ossie Davis died on 4 February 2005 and was found dead last weekend in his hotel room in Florida.
3. The text emphasizes the importance of Ossie Davis's contributions to the Civil Rights Movement, including his role as a co-star with Spike Lee in the 1970s TV comedy Evening Shade.
4. The article quotes several people who were close to Ossie Davis, including actor Alan Alda and civil rights activist Malcolm X.
5. The text also mentions that Ossie Davis was a beloved figure in Harlem and that his legacy will continue to inspire future generations of activists and artists.

granite3.1-dense:2b:

Davis, a prominent civil rights activist and 87-year-old veteran, died on February 4, 2005, from natural causes while filming in Miami. His wife of 56 years, Ruby Dee, was present at the service along with former US President Bill Clinton and singer Harry Belafonte, who delivered a eulogy highlighting Davis's potential as a president.

Davis began his acting career in 1950 and collaborated frequently with director Spike Lee, appearing in films like Jungle Fever, Do The Right Thing, and Malcolm X. His famous daughter, Attallah Shabazz, recalled a moving eulogy delivered at her father's funeral by Davis. Aviator star Alan Alda expressed his admiration for Davis as "a thing of beauty" and aspired to emulate some of his qualities. Burt Reynolds called Davis his hero.

Before the service, Harlem residents formed a line outside the church to pay their respects. Harry Belafonte, an ardent civil rights activist and friend of Davis for over 60 years, delivered a poignant tribute, acknowledging the profound impact Davis had on his life and lamenting that Harlem would no longer benefit from his wisdom, humor, loyalty, and moral strength.
